g.text: Figure S1a,b shows the distributions of correlation coefficients between observed surface temperature and
ASO. The variations in ASO are closely linked to surface temperature changes in the middle of the Eurasian
continent. This phenomenon has been reported in previous studies using observations
It illustrates that the ASO variations connected with the surface temperature anomalies over the middle of the
Eurasian continent can be found in observations, supporting that simulated surface temperature in the middle of
the Eurasian continent is improved in E
as a result of improved stratospheric ozone forcing.
The time series of simulated globally averaged surface temperature. (
averaged annual surface temperature anomalies for the period 1979–2005 from E
), but for surface temperature from E
), but for surface temperature from E
(blue line) and HadCRUT4 (red line). The anomalies are obtained by removing
the seasonal cycle and the time series are detrended. The correlation coefficients (
are shown in the top right corner and the “
is significant at the 95% confidence level. The values in
bracket are uncertainty range for the correlation coefficient at the 95% confidence level.
The spatial distribution of simulated global surface temperature. (
correlation coefficients between global surface temperature variations from E
), but for surface temperature from E
), but for surface temperature from E
Surface temperature variations are obtained by removing the seasonal cycle and are detrended. Only positive
correlations coefficients are shown. In the color bar, the values 0.136, 0.255, 0.323, 0.381, 0.445 and 0.487
correspond to the 80%, 85%, 90%, 95%, 99% and 99.9% confidence levels, respectively.
